questions.question: Match the following antibiotics with their appropriate mechanism of action. Drugs Mechanism of action 1 Linezolid A. Blocks 50s ribosomal subunit; interferes with translocation 2 Tetracycline B. Block 23s subunit on 50s ribosome, interferes with formylmethionine-tRNA 70S complex formation 3 Erythromycin C. Blocks 30s ribosomal subunit; causes misreading of mRNA 4 Streptomycin D. Blocks 30S mRNA-ribosome; inhibits attachment of aminoacyl-t-RNA to the acceptor (A) site.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1- B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C Explanation: Drugs Ribosomal subunit blocked Effect Linezolid Block 23s subunit on 50s ribosome. Interferes with formylmethionine-tRNA 70S initiation complex formation, thus preventing protein synthesis. Tetracycline /tigecycline Doxycycline Demeclocycline Minocycline Blocks 30S mRNA - ribosome. Inhibits attachment of aminoacyl-t-RNA to the acceptor (A) site. Aminoglycosides Streptomycin Amikacin Misreading of mRNA Inhibit polysome formation (Attachment of ribosomes on mRNA) Inhibits initiation of protein synthesis Chloramphenicol Blocks 50s ribosomal subunit. Inhibits transfer of the elongating peptide chain to the newly attached aminoacyl-tRNA. Macrolides Erythromycin Azithromycin Interferes with translocation. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 784, 790, 793, 801, 807

questions.question: A drug sensitivity test of a patient's sputum sample shows the presence of vancomycin-resistant MRSA. A narrow-spectrum protein synthesis inhibitor antibiotic that inhibits the formation of formylmethionine-tRNA 70S initiation complex was started for the patient. Which drug was most likely used?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Linezolid Explanation: In the above scenario, the patient's sample shows the presence of vancomycin-resistant MRSA, a multi-drug-resistant strain for whom linezolid is reserved. Linezolid is a narrow-spectrum protein synthesis inhibitor that targets only gram-positive bacteria. Mechanism of action: Inhibition of the formation of the formylmethionine-tRNA 70S initiation complex, thus preventing the initiation of protein synthesis. Spectrum Antibiotics Uses Broad spectrum Effective against a wide range of bacteria, including both Gram-positive and Gram-negative organisms. Chloramphenicol (Option C) Pyogenic meningitis (Second line) Endophthalmitis Anaerobic infections Tetracycline Chlamydia Bacillus anthrax Psittacosis Clindamycin (Option D) Ance Anaerobic infections Drug-resistant Malaria Toxoplasmosis Intermediate spectrum Typically, they cover Gram-positive or Gram-negative bacteria, but not both extensively. Macrolides Azithromycin (Option A) Erythromycin Atypical pneumonia Whooping cough Chlamydia Narrow spectrum Effective against a limited range of bacteria. Aminoglycoside Streptomycin Amikacin Tuberculosis Tularemia Neonatal sepsis Linezolid (Option B) Vancomycin-resistant MRSA. VRE. Streptogramin MRSA Penicillin-resistant streptococcus pneumonia. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 754, 785, 790, 792, 798, 805

questions.question: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding Chloramphenicol?

options.A: It is metabolised via hepatic conjugation
options.B: It can cause dose-dependent marrow suppression
options.C: It can be safely used in neonates
options.D: Resistance occurs due to plasmid-mediated inactivation by bacteria.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) It can be safely used in neonates Explanation: Chloramphenicol should be avoided in neonates due to their immature liver, which leads to toxicity. This results in "grey baby syndrome," characterised by hypotonia, distended abdomen, irregular respiration, ashen grey cyanosis, elevated lactic acid levels, cardiovascular collapse, and potentially death. Category Description Mechanism of Action Inhibits protein synthesis by blocking the 50s ribosomal subunit, preventing peptide chain elongation. Absorption & Distribution Rapidly absorbed, has a high volume of distribution (1 L/kg), has good CSF penetration, and freely penetrates bodily cavities. Excretion Excreted via hepatic glucuronidation. (Option A) Drug Interactions Inhibits metabolism of warfarin, cyclophosphamide, and phenytoin. Enhanced metabolism by phenobarbitone, phenytoin, and rifampin. Resistance Mechanisms Plasmid-mediated inactivation by bacteria decreases penetration into bacteria. (Option D) Uses Second line for pyogenic meningitis, endophthalmitis, anaerobic infections Side Effects Dose-dependent marrow suppression. (Option B) Dose-independent idiosyncratic reaction. Hypersensitivity. Grey baby syndrome. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 790-792.

questions.question: A 22-year-old man with a history of multiple sexual partners comes to the clinic with an inguinal swelling. Physical examination findings are given below. What would be the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Doxycycline Explanation: Lymphogranuloma venereum is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, and the drug of choice is Doxycycline + Azithromycin. Doxycycline is a member of the tetracycline group. It is a protein synthesis inhibitor that blocks 30S mRNA-ribosome, thus inhibiting the attachment of aminoacyl-t-RNA to the acceptor (A) site. Tetracyclines: Features Tetracycline Oxytetracycline Demeclocycline Doxycycline Minocycline Potency Low Intermediate High Plasma protein binding Low High high Half-life 6 - 12 hours 10 -16 hours 18- 24 hours Alteration of gut flora Altered Moderate alteration Least alteration Phototoxicity Low Highest High Other toxicity Tooth discoloration is less marked Diabetes insipidus Doxycycline has low nephrotoxicity. Minocycline has 0totoxicity. Uses of Tetracyclines Chlamydial Infections : Urethritis, Endocervicitis, Lymphogranuloma venereum, granuloma inguinale. Atypical Pneumonia: Mycoplasma pneumonia, Psittacosis. Rickettsial Infections. Pleurodesis: Doxycycline for pneumothorax. H. pylori Infection: Part of quadruple therapy. Anthrax, Plague, Borrelia. Penicillin G (Option A) is a beta-lactam antibiotic that inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis and is used to treat syphilis. Cefixime (Option C) is a third-generation cephalosporin that inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis and is used to treat gonorrhoea. Acyclovir (Option D) is an anti-viral agent that inhibits viral DNA polymerase, which is used to treat herpes infection. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 767, 770, 776, 784-789, 850

questions.question: A 26-year-old pregnant woman was treated with an antibiotic for chlamydia during-her 6th month of pregnancy. Nine months later, she delivered a healthy baby boy. As the child grew, he developed teeth resembling those in the provided image and had a short stature. Which antibiotic was most likely used?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Tetracyclines Explanation: Tetracyclines are contraindicated in pregnancy, lactation, and children due to the risk of calcium-tetracycline chelation, which can lead to permanent yellowish discolouration of teeth and inhibited bone growth. It should also be avoided with dairy products as they reduce drug absorption. Contraindication of tetracycline : Pregnancy Children During lactation Renal failure (Except Doxyxline) Adverse effects of tetracycline are: Acute hepatic necrosis: seen in pregnancy Fanconi syndrome Photosensitivity Permanent discolouration of teeth (due to in-utero exposure) Delayed growth Diabetes insipidus Rarely, â†‘ ICP in children/pseudotumor cerebri Vestibulotoxic (minocycline) Exfoliative dermatitis (hypersensitivity reaction) Amikacin (Option B) is also contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity, but it does not affect bone growth or tooth colour. Chloramphenicol (Option C) is contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of 'grey baby syndrome', which can lead to severe symptoms like hypotonia, distended abdomen, cyanosis, and cardiovascular collapse. Sulfonamide ( Option D) is a sulfa drug that displaces bilirubin from albumin, leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which leads to kernicterus. Thus, it should be avoided during pregnancy and in neonates. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Pages 756, 784-792

questions.question: Which of the following antimicrobials is safe for use in neonates?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Azithromycin Explanation: Azithromycin is considered safer for use in neonates. It is often used in neonates to treat infections such as chlamydia conjunctivitis and pneumonia. Azithromycin Mechanism of Action Azithromycin inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit, interfering with the elongation of the polypeptide chain and ultimately halting bacterial growth. Pharmacokinetics Excellent intracellular penetration, allowing it to effectively target intracellular pathogens. This intracellular accumulation contributes to its prolonged half-life. Once-daily dosing Hepatic clearance does not cross the blood-brain barrier. Common Uses Respiratory Infections (e.g., pneumonia (atypical), bronchitis) Genitourinary Infections (e.g., Chlamydia trachomatis) Skin and Soft Tissue Infections (e.g., cellulitis) Other Infections (e.g., otitis media, pharyngitis) Side Effects Mild gastric upset Abdominal pain Headache Dizziness Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 804

questions.question: Which of the following antibiotics is commonly used in triple therapy to treat H. pylori infection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Clarithromycin Explanation: The triple therapy regimen for H. pylori you provided is as follows: Lansoprazole: 30 mg Amoxicillin: 1000 mg Clarithromycin: 500 mg Aspect Clarithromycin Mechanism of Action Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit. Uses Upper and lower respiratory tract infections, otitis media, whooping cough, atypical pneumonia, H. pylori eradication, MAC infection in AIDS patients, other atypical mycobacterial diseases, and leprosy. Side Effects Gastric intolerance, reversible hearing loss (at high doses), hepatic dysfunction, rhabdomyolysis (rare), and CYP3A4 inhibition lead to potential drug interactions. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 803

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding Erythromycin?

options.B: Erythromycin is stable in an acidic environment.
options.C: Have a large volume of distribution, allowing for extensive tissue penetration.
options.D: Highly lipid-soluble, allowing for excellent penetration into the central nervous system

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Have a large volume of distribution, allowing for extensive tissue penetration. CNS , reflecting a large volume of distribution (Vd) . It accumulates intracellularly and achieves therapeutic levels in various tissues, supporting its use in respiratory and soft tissue infections. Pharmacokinetic features of erythromycin: Property Details Volume of distribution High , with extensive tissue penetration Acid stability Unstable in acidic pH (why enteric-coated or esterified forms are used) Route of excretion Mainly hepatic , via bile CNS penetration Poor , due to limited lipid solubility Primarily eliminated through renal excretion (Option A): Incorrect because erythromycin is excreted via the bile , not primarily by the kidneys. Erythromycin is stable in an acidic environment (Option B): Incorrect because erythromycin is acid-labile , which is why formulations like erythromycin estolate or enteric coatings are used. Highly lipid-soluble, allowing for excellent penetration into the central nervous system (Option D): Incorrect because erythromycin does not penetrate the CNS well and is not highly lipid-soluble . Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 804

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with severe diarrhoea and abdominal pain after recently being treated with an antibiotic for a skin infection. Stool tests confirm the presence of Clostridium difficile. Which of the following antibiotics is associated with the highest risk of causing pseudomembranous colitis in this clinical scenario?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Clindamycin Explanation: The antibiotic most commonly implicated in causing pseudomembranous colitis is Clindamycin. Clindamycin Mechanism of Action Inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosome. Spectrum of Activity Effective against gram-positive cocci, Clostridium spp., Nocardia, Actinomyces, Toxoplasma Use Anaerobic and mixed infections, especially those caused by Bacteroides fragilis, can lead to conditions like abdominal and pelvic abscesses, lung abscesses, septic abortion, and infections from penetrating injuries. Adverse Effects Rashes, urticaria, abdominal pain. Liver damage Thrombophlebitis at the injection site. Major concern: Pseudomembranous enterocolitis due to Clostridium difficile superinfection, potentially fatal. Erythromycin (Option A) , Tetracycline (Option B) , and Ciprofloxacin (Option D) are less commonly associated with pseudomembranous colitis than clindamycin. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 805

questions.question: A 65-year-old patient with renal failure presents with a suspected Gram-positive bacterial infection. The patient's creatinine clearance is significantly reduced. Which antibiotic would be the most appropriate choice for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Linezolid Explanation: Linezolid is the preferred choice for this patient due to its hepatic metabolism and non-renal excretion, which enhances safety in individuals with renal impair Linezolid Mechanism of Action It inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 23S ribosomal RNA of the P site of 50S ribosomal subunit. It interferes with the formation of the ternary N-formylmethionyl-tRNA (tRNAf-Met)-70S initiation complex, preventing the initiation of protein synthesis. Spectrum of Activity Gram-positive cocci (aerobic and anaerobic): MRSA, VRSA, VRE, Strep. viridans, Strep. pneumoniae Other sensitive bacteria: Clostridia, B. fragilis, M. tuberculosis. Common Uses Uncomplicated and complicated skin and soft tissue infections Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAPs) Bacteremia. Side Effects Mild abdominal pain, nausea and diarrhoea. Chorioretinitis Optic neuritis Bone marrow suppression (monitor platelet count) Caution is advised when used concurrently with MAO inhibitors due to the risk of serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 807

questions.question: A 68-year-old woman with diabetes and chronic kidney disease is hospitalised for a severe diabetic foot infection, likely due to MRSA. The doctor is considering a Streptogramin antibiotic. Which of the following statements about Streptogramins is correct?

options.A: Inhibit bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.
options.B: Cover both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria.
options.D: The most common adverse effect is nephrotoxicity.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Streptogramins inhibit bacterial protein synthesis through binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit. Explanations: Streptogramins (e.g., quinupristin-dalfopristin) are bacteriostatic agents that work by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit . This binding inhibits protein synthesis and results in a synergistic effect , making the combination bactericidal against many Gram-positive organisms. They are used in multi-drug-resistant Gram-positive infections , especially MRSA and vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium . Streptogramins: Feature Details Mechanism of Action Inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit Examples Quinupristin-Dalfopristin (used in fixed combination) Spectrum of Activity Mainly Gram-positive cocci (MRSA, VRE faecium) Adverse Effects Phlebitis , arthralgia, myalgia, elevated bilirubin (not nephrotoxicity) Excretion Primarily hepatic (safe in renal dysfunction) Cover both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria (Option B): Incorrect. Streptogramins have no significant activity against Gram-negative organisms , especially due to efflux pumps and enzymatic resistance. First-line therapy for community-acquired pneumonia (Option C): Incorrect. Streptogramins are not first-line ; macrolides, fluoroquinolones, or beta-lactams are preferred. Streptogramins are reserved for resistant Gram-positive infections . The most common adverse effect is nephrotoxicity (Option D): Incorrect. Streptogramins are not nephrotoxic . Common side effects include phlebitis , arthralgia , and myalgia . Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 808

questions.question: A 55-year-old diabetic man presents with a severe UTI, showing high fever, chills, and dysuria. Urine culture reveals E. coli resistant to aminoglycosides and fluoroquinolones. What mechanism likely contributes to E. coli's resistance to aminoglycosides?

options.A: Inactivation of the drug by bacterial enzymes
options.B: Alteration of the bacterial ribosomal binding site
options.C: Decreased uptake of the drug into bacterial cells
options.D: Formation of biofilms on mucosal surfaces

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Inactivation of the drug by bacterial enzymes Explanation: Aminoglycoside resistance typically involves modification by bacterial enzymes like acetyltransferases, phosphotransferases, and nucleotidyltransferases. These enzymes alter aminoglycosides, preventing their binding to bacterial ribosomes and blocking protein synthesis. This resistance mechanism is common in multidrug-resistant bacteria, including those causing urinary tract infections (UTIs). Aminoglycosides Mechanism of action Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit, causing misreading of mRNA. Drugs Streptomycin, Gentamicin, Tobramycin, Amikacin, Neomycin, Netilmicin Spectrum Primarily Gram-negative aerobic bacteria; limited Gram-positive coverage. Includes Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Enterobacteriaceae. Uses Serious Gram-negative infections (e.g., sepsis, pneumonia) Tuberculosis (Streptomycin) Endocarditis (Gentamicin in combination therapy) Resistance mechanism Enzymatic inactivation by acetyltransferases, phosphotransferases, and nucleotidyltransferases. Alteration of the 30S ribosomal binding site. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 793-800

questions.question: Which adverse effects are most commonly associated with aminoglycosides?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity Explanation: Adverse Effect Mechanism of Action Reversibility Risk Order Ototoxicity Damages hair cells (neurons projecting into endolymph). Cochlear damage leads to high-frequency hearing loss. Vestibular damage leads to imbalance, ataxia, vertigo. Irreversible. Neomycin > Amikacin > Kanamycin. Nephrotoxicity Damages tubular cells of nephron (PCT, DCT), leading to renal tubular acidosis. Reversible. Neomycin > Gentamicin > Streptomycin. Neuromuscular Blockade Inhibits release of ACh and blocks Nm receptor, leading to muscle paralysis Contraindicated in Myasthenia gravis Partially reversible with calcium salts. Neomycin > Streptomycin > Tobramycin. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Pg 794-795

questions.question: Which antibiotics will be least helpful in treating Enterococcus faecium infection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Ampicillin Explanation: Ampicillin inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding to PBPs. However, it is least effective against E. faecium strains due to resistance caused by altered PBPs. Drugs useful in Enterococcus infection: Drug Mechanism of Action (MOA) Vancomycin Inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding to the D-alanyl-D-alanine terminus of cell wall precursor units. Linezolid (Option B) Inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit. Daptomycin (Option C) Causes rapid depolarisation of bacterial membrane potential, inhibiting protein, DNA, and RNA synthesis. Nitrofurantoin Reduced by bacterial enzymes to reactive intermediates, altering or inactivating bacterial ribosomal proteins. Tigecycline (Option D) Inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 807

questions.question: A 72-year-old woman with COPD develops severe diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, and fever two weeks after being treated with ceftriaxone and clindamycin. Stool testing confirms Clostridioides difficile infection. An endoscopic image shows pseudomembranous colitis. Which antibiotic is the most appropriate for treating her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Fidaxomicin Explanation: Fidaxomicin is the best choice for treating severe pseudomembranous enterocolitis caused by Clostridioides difficile. It specifically targets C. difficile, minimising disruption to the gut microbiome and reducing recurrence risk compared to broad-spectrum antibiotics like metronidazole or vancomycin. Mechanism of action:
